metadata.title: Electrodeposition of graphene nano-thick coating for highly enhanced performance of titanium bipolar plates in fuel cells

sections.text:
ww.sciencedirect.com

ScienceDirect
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/he
Electrodeposition of graphene nano-thick coating for highly enhanced performance of titanium bipolar plates in fuel cells
Jianyu Wang, Luofu Min, Feifei Fang, Wen Zhang**, Yuxin Wang*

sections.heading: State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, Co-Innovation Center of Chemical Science & Engineering, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Membrane Science & Desalination Technology, School of Chemical Engineering, Tianjin University,
sections.text:
Tianjin, 300072, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o

sections.heading: Article history:
sections.text: Received 4 March 2019 Received in revised form 16 April 2019 Accepted 23 April 2019 Available online 17 May 2019

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Graphene film Pulse electrodeposition Titanium Corrosion Bipolar plates Fuel cell
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: zhang_wen@tju.edu.cn https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2019.04.245 0360-3199/© 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publicati
a b s t r a c t
We report in this paper a simple method of coating very thin graphene film on titanium substrate, affording it markedly enhanced resistance to corrosion and much decreased electrical contact resistance under the environment of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC). The graphene film is formed by electrodepositing graphene oxide (GO) on Ti sheet via normal pulse voltammetry, followed by reducing the deposited GO at 500 C in hydrogen atmosphere. The resultant graphene film, with a thickness of only around 50 nm, evenly covers and covalently bonds to the Ti sheet, as revealed by SEM, Raman and XPS. Both potentiodynamic and potentiostatic tests of the graphene coated Ti (G/Ti) sample are conducted under simulated chemical environment and electrode potentials of PEMFC. Under all the circumstances, the corrosion currents of G/Ti sheet are in the order of 10 7 A/ cm2, significantly less than that of bare Ti sheet. Moreover, the coated graphene film on Ti sheet leads to a much lower and more stable interfacial contact resistance (ICR) of around 4 mU cm2. These results mean that the G/Ti sheet meets the U.S. DOE target of 2020 for PEMFC bipolar plates (BP) in terms of both the corrosion and electrical resistance. Therefore, the G/Ti sheet appears to be a very promising BP material in PEMFC.
© 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) is a very promising power source in diverse applications, not only for its high efficiency and low/zero emission, but also owing to its high power density, low working temperature and quick start-up [1e9]. As one of the most important components of PEMFC, bipolar plates (BP) carry out multiple functions: distributing
(W. Zhang), yxwang@tju
ons LLC. Published by Els
the fuel and oxidant, moving out produced water and heat, connecting single cells and conducting electric current between them [2,10e15]. As such, BP should possess good mechanical strength, impermeability to gas and liquid, high electrical and thermal conductivity, and high corrosion resistance in the acidic and humid environment of PEMFC. Besides, BP should be low in cost and fabricated effectively to ensure the economic competitiveness of the PEMFC power
.edu.cn (Y. Wang).
evier Ltd. All rights reserved.
source. The simultaneous fulfillment of those requirements proves to be very challenging so far.
Conventionally, the BP in PEMFC are made from graphite because of its high resistance to corrosion, as well as high electrical and thermal conductivity [10,16e18]. However, graphite is brittle so that graphite BP usually have to be rather thick to withstand machining and handling. Largely for the same reason, graphite BP also suffer from highmanufacturing cost. All thesemay lead to bulky, heavy and expensive fuel cell stacks, thus limiting their applications.
Superior to graphite in many aspects [19,20], metals have been suggested as an alternative. Stainless steel, titanium and a number of other metals were explored as the candidate material for making BP in PEMFC [2,4,5,12,16,19,21e30]. Metal BP can be made with a thickness in the sub-millimeter scale, enabling the PEMFC power sources to achieve unprecedented high power density. However, metal BP can be corroded in the PEMFC environment, releasing metal ions which may poison catalysts or forming passive films which can increase the interfacial contact resistance (ICR) and thus ohmic loss.
Titanium is known for its high specific strength, good ductility and excellent resistance to corrosion [31], suggesting it is a great choice formaking BP. Yet it turned out that passive films with increasing electrical resistance would form on Ti BP, thus deteriorating the PEMFC power output. To tackle this problem, extensive efforts have been made to protect Ti BP from corrosion with various coatings. Wang et al. [32,33] tried to protect Ti BP with Pt, Ir and Au coatings respectively, and found the noble metal coatings do lead to enhanced plate and cell performances. Jung et al. [25] deposited a 1 mmAu layer on titanium by a sputtering method and found that the Au coating can prevent effectively the oxidation of titanium. Zhang et al. [24] deposited TiN on Ti substrate via multi-arc ion plating. Their results showed the TiN coating can greatly improve the resistance to corrosion and reduce the ICR. Feng et al. [34] coated titanium oxy-nitride layers on titanium at different temperatures through nitrogen plasma immersion ion implantation. They found that higher temperature coating leads to thicker titanium oxy-nitride layer and better performance in simulated PEMFC environment. Gao et al. [14] prepared a C/PTFE/TiN composite coating on Ti substrates through a two-step hydrothermal and impregnation process, resulting in a satisfactory corrosion current of <1 mA/cm2, relatively low ICR of 13 mU cm2 and increased hydrophobicity (contact angle 120 ). While coating proves to be an effective means to tackle Ti corrosion problem in PEMFC, previous coating strategies suffer to different extent from employing noble metal materials, expensive equipment or complicated processes. Additionally, the technical requirements on BP in PEMFC have been raising [35]. More satisfactory coating strategies for Ti BP are well worth pursuing.
In this paper, we report a simplemethod of coating Ti sheet with nano-thick graphene film, providing the Ti sheet with markedly enhanced resistance to corrosion and much decreased electrical contact resistance under PEMFC environment. The method consists of pulse electrodepositing GO and chemically reducing GO to graphene, involving no rare and expensive materials and no complicated equipment. The excellent anti-corrosion property of reduced GO and graphene
is well known [36e38], and electrodeposition is an frequently used way to coat a metal surface [39e42]. But there is no previous report on the fabrication of graphene coating on Ti substrate via electrodeposition, to the best of our knowledge. We show in this paper our method of coating graphene on Ti and the feasibility of the graphene coated Ti as BP in PEMFC. It turns out that the graphene coated Ti meets the U.S. DOE targets of 2020 for bipolar plates in terms of the corrosion and electrical resistances, indicating themethod is very promising for protecting Ti BP in PEMFC.

sections.heading: Materials and reagents
sections.text: Titanium sheets (Ta1, Ti content 99.5%, thickness 0.06 mm) were supplied by ZhixinlongMetal Product Co., Foshan, China. Graphite powder (carbon content 99%, average size 40 mm) was purchased from Xianfeng Nano Co., Nanjing, China. Hydrogen (99.99%), nitrogen (99.99%) gases and air (99.99%) were supplied by Dongxiang Special Gas Co., Tianjin, China. Potassium permanganate (KMnO4), sodium nitrate (NaNO3) and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 40%) were bought from Kermel Chemical Reagent Co, Tianjin, China. Sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98%), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%), acetone and ethanol were purchased from Guangfu Fine Chemical Research Institute, Tianjin, China. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30%) and was purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Shanghai, China. Deionized water ( 3 MU cm) was supplied by Yongqingyuan Environmental Science and Technology Co., Tianjin, China.

sections.heading: Sample preparation
sections.text:
Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared from graphite power by a modified Hummers' method [43]. Typically, 2 g graphite powder and 2 g NaNO3 was mixed via stirring with 46 ml H2SO4 in a beaker at around 0 C. Then 6 g KMnO4 was slowly added into the mixture, keeping its temperature below 20 C. Afterwards, the mixture was heated to 35 Cand kept for 30 min, followed by adding 120 ml deionized water, heating to 95 C and keeping for 30 min. The reaction in the mixture was terminated by first putting in 160ml deionizedwater, followed by dropwise adding 30 ml H2O2. The resulting mixture was centrifuged, filtered, washed with 10% HCl repeatedly, dialyzed until it approached neutral, and finally dried to obtain graphitic oxide. A specified amount of graphitic oxide was ultrasonically exfoliated in deionized water for 0.5 h to obtain a 1.0 mg/ml GO suspension, which was later used as the coating agent.
Prior to electrodeposition, the received bare Ti sheets, referred to as unpretreated Ti, were successively pretreated via mechanical polishing with SiC sandpapers of different grades, stripping oxide layer with 20%wt H2SO4 at 80 C and sequentially sonicating in acetone, ethanol and deionized water. The electrodeposition was carried out in a threeelectrode cell, with the pretreated Ti sheet, a Pt sheet and a saturated calomel electrode as the working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. The GO
coating agent was directly used as the electrolyte. A normal pulse voltammetry (NPV) was employed, exerting an increasing voltage from 0 to 10 V, with a step height of 10 mV, and a duty cycle of 0.5 (ton ¼ 0.5 s, toff ¼ 0.5 s). After the electrodeposition, the GO coated Ti (GO/Ti) sheet was dried at room temperature for 2 h and subsequently heated at 500 C in hydrogen atmosphere for 2 h, reducing GO to graphene to obtain graphene coated Ti sheet (G/Ti).

sections.heading: Characterization and measurements
sections.text:
The samples' morphologies were imaged via scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi, S4800). The cross-section of G/ Ti for SEM imaging was revealed via argon ion beam milling (Leica EM TIC 3X). Energy dispersive X-rays spectroscopy (EDS, Thermo Scientific NORAN system 7) was used to uncover the atomic distribution along the cross-section area. The chemical structure of the electrodeposited graphene film was detected via Raman spectroscopy (Raman, Renishaw, Invia), with a 532 nm Nd:YAG laser as excitation source. The surface composition of samples was measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo, ESCALAB 250Xi), using a Al Ka source. All the binding energies in the XPS spectra were referenced to the C1s peak at 284.8 eV.
The electrochemical corrosion of different Ti sheets was tested via potentiodynamic and potentiostatic polarization methods separately, using the same setup as in the electrodeposition. But here the electrolyte was changed to a 0.5 M H2SO4 þ 2 ppm HF solution at 70 C with H2 or air gas bubbling, to imitate the anodic or cathodic PEMFC environment. Also, the Ti sheet was largely covered with epoxy resin, leaving only a small area at one side exposed to the electrolyte. Before polarization measurements, the sample to be tested was allowed to stabilize in the electrolyte at open circuit potential (OCP) for 1 h. In the potentiodynamic tests, the potential scan was in a ±250 mV range centered in the OCP at a rate of 1 mV/s. While for the potentiostatic tests, the anodic or cathodic polarizations were at 0.1 V or þ0.6 V (vs. SCE), respectively.
The interfacial contact resistance (ICR) between a sample sheet and carbon paper (Toray, TGP-H-060), a commonly used gas diffusion layer (GDL) in PEMFC, was measured following Ref. [16]. To obtain ICR, the total resistance of a single piece of carbon paper R1 and the total resistance of the sample sandwiched between two pieces of carbon paper R2 were separately measured under the compaction force ranging from 30 to 180 N/cm2. R1 consists of the bulk resistance of carbon paper Rcp and the interfacial resistance arising from its contact with the measuring electrodes, while R2 is composed of R1, additional Rcp, the bulk resistance of the Ti sheet and the ICR. As the bulk resistance of a Ti sheet is negligible compared with R1, R2, and Rcp, the ICR under a given compaction force can be calculated via the equation:
ICR¼ R2 R1 Rcp $A=2 (1)
where A is the effective surface area of the sample. In the case of a sample with GO or graphene coating, the bulk resistance of the carbonic film is counted in ICR, as implied in Eq. (1).

sections.heading: Coating, morphology and structure
sections.text:
Our coating agent, with its negatively charged GO nanosheets, is similar to an electrophoretic paint. So the formation of GO film on Ti sheets can be understood as an anodic deposition. The accumulation and solidification of GO nanosheets on the Ti surface could be ascribed to three combined mechanisms [36]: (a) The GO nanosheets, bearing negative charges, e.g. via carboxyls, migrate and accumulate via electrophoresis to the Ti sheet anode, forming GO hydrogel; (b) Negatively charged GO nanosheets composing the hydrogel are neutralized by protons generated at the anode via water electrolysis, diminishing the electrostatic repulsion with each other and thus facilitating their solidification; (c) Protons created at the anode carry water molecules out of the GO hydrogel via electroosmosis, leading to a more condensed GO layer.
The purpose of employing a NPV mode in GO electrodeposition is to mitigate the interruption of gas bubbles and the concentration polarization of GO nanosheets near the anode surface. These happened under the mode of constantpotential and resulted in coarse and uneven GO films (Fig. S1). In contrast, the GO film formed under the NPV mode appears smooth and densely packed, though with scattered wrinkles typical of GO nanosheets (Fig. 1a). Interestingly, the wrinkles on the GO film completely disappear on its way of converting to graphene film under H2 atmosphere at 500 C (Fig. 1b). The disappearance of the wrinkles is presumably due to the loss of oxygen-containing groups from the GO nanosheets in the high temperature H2 atmosphere, which facilitates a rearrangement of reduced GO nanosheets to a more compact form.
The graphene film derived from reducing GO film in the high temperature H2 atmosphere proves to be fairly robust. The surface morphology of G/Ti sheet displays no visible difference before and after a 5 h polarization in the simulated cathodic PEMFC environment (Fig. 1b and c). Moreover, the qualitative tests by either thermal shocking or scribing indicate that the adhesion of graphene film on Ti substrate is reasonably strong (Fig. S2). The robustness of graphene film should have to do with the high temperature treatment, which usually enhances the adhesion between similar or dissimilar materials [44,45]. The very low thickness of the graphene film, about 50 nm as shown in Fig. 1d, may also contribute to its robustness, as the stress needed for a thin material to deform is relatively low and so its chance to break.
The Raman maps of GO/Ti and G/Ti samples are shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S3. The D-peak (1352 cm 1) and G-peak (1593 cm 1) characteristic of GO and graphene can be seen everywhere in the mapped area, indicating fairly homogeneous and full coverage of GO or graphene film on Ti substrate. The noticeably high intensity of D-peak (Fig. S4) reveals that there are many defects in both GO and graphene films, which is understandable considering the process in making the films. Nonetheless, G/Ti's average ratio of intensities of Dpeak to G-peak, an indicator of the degree of graphitization [46,47], is obviously smaller compared with GO/Ti, showing
the effectiveness of using high temperature H2 for GO reduction.
The effectiveness of GO reduction to graphene is more clearly demonstrated by XPS results. The high resolution XPS spectrum at C 1s region shows that there exist substantial oxygen containing species, CeOeC, CeOH, C(O)O and C]O, on the top surface of GO/Ti (Fig. 3a). Whereas in the case of G/ Ti, the oxygen containing species diminish to different extent and graphitic carbon becomes the only predominant species (Fig. 3b), as a result of the high temperature H2 treatment. It is noted that no Ti species on the top surface of GO/Ti or G/Ti can
be detected from the XPS spectra (Fig. 3c and d), confirming the full coverage of carbonic film revealed from the Raman results (Fig. 2).
After stripped off a 50 nm layer from the top of G/Ti through argon ion beam eaching, the sample's XPS spectra shows some new information. Now there appears a high intensity Ti 2p peak (~459 eV), whereas the C 1s peak (~285 eV) becomes very week (Fig. 4a,c,d), suggesting almost all the graphene film has been etched away and the irradiating X-ray starts to penetrate Ti substrate. Therefore, the graphene film on G/Ti should be about 50nm in thickness,which agreeswith both the SEMobservation
and EDS analysis (Fig. 1d). It is also noticed that TieOeC species can be detected in O 1s (531.2 eV [48]) and C 1s (287.7 eV) spectra (Fig. 4b,d), suggesting the graphene film and Ti substrate is chemicallybondedtogether throughbridgingoxygen.Theraised
oxygencontentat the interfaceofgraphenefilmandTisubstrate detected by EDS (Fig. 1d) seems to serve as an additional evidence. These results providean important clue to rationalize the strong adhesion of the graphene film to Ti substrate.

sections.heading: Corrosion and electrical contact
sections.text:
The potentiodynamic polarization curves of three different samples, i.e. unpretreated Ti, pretreated Ti and G/Ti, under different PEMFC environments are presented in Fig. 5, from which the samples' respective corrosion current Icorr and corrosion potential Ecorr are obtained and summarized in Table 1. As expected, the corrosion current of pretreated Ti, having its passive oxide layer stripped out, is considerably higher than that of the unpretreated counterpart. As the anticorrosion property of Ti arises from its passive oxide layer on the surface, the unpretreated Ti better resist corrosion. Unfortunately, that passive oxide layer neither adequately protects Ti BP in PEMFC, nor sufficiently conduct electricity [16,25,39], which justifies the need of devising special coating strategies for Ti BP. G/Ti surpasses bare Ti, either pretreated or not, in that its corrosion currents are at least an order of magnitude smaller, reaching 2.7 10 7 and 2.5 10 7 A/cm2 under anodic and cathodic conditions (Table 1). The corrosion potentials of G/Ti are also noticeably higher then that of bare Ti, indicating increased corrosion barrier because of the thin graphene film on Ti. The markedly increased anti-corrosion ability of G/Ti is attributed to the excellent anti-corrosion property fo graphene [16,49]and its full coverage on the Ti sheet.
The potentiostatic polarization tests also show that the electrodeposited graphene film is very effective in protecting Ti substrate from corrosion under simulated PEMFC operating conditions in both electrodes (Fig. 6 and Table 2). The
Table 1 e A summary of the results of potentiodynamic corrosion tests based on the polarization curves shown in Fig. 5.
Samples Anodic condition Cathodic condition
Icorr (mA/cm2) Ecorr(V) Icorr (mA/cm2) Ecorr(V)
G/Ti 0.27 0.05 0.25 0.05 Ti-unpretreated 7.05 0.11 3.02 0.11 Ti-pretreated 300 0.60 286 0.60
corrosion currents of pretreated bare Ti are in the order of 10 4 A/cm2 at the start, gradually decay because of Ti passivation, and approach to around 5 10 6 A/cm2 after about 3 h. In contrast, the corrosion currents of G/Ti drop to around 2 10 7 A/cm2 in almost no time and then remain constant in the whole range of 5 h test. Thus the corrosion inhibition of the thin graphene film is not only very evident but also quite stable. Moreover, the corrosion inhibition achieved is better thanmost previously reported (As shown in Table S1) andwell meets the U.S. DOE 2020 target of corrosion current (1 10 6 A/cm2) for BP [35]. In addition to corrosion inhibition, the thin graphene film on Ti sheet should simultaneously be a good conductor and exhibit low ICR when touching a GDL, to meet the basic requirements on BP. Fig. 7 shows the ICR of G/Ti and unpretreated Ti varied with compaction force. It is seen clearly that the ICR of unpretreated Ti is much higher. Furthermore, it increases noticeably after 5 h of potentiostatic polarization at anodic or cathodic condition. In contrast, G/Ti hasmuch lower ICR of around 4 mU cm2 and the increase of ICR is hardly appreciable after going through the same polarization. In fact, the ICR achieved in G/Ti is among the best of various coated Ti bipolar plates reported (See Table S1).
Because the bulk resistance of the graphene film has been included in its ICR, as mentioned in the experimental section, the total through-plate resistance (TPR) of a G/Ti sheet should be the sum of the resistance of Ti and ICR at the two sides. But the resistance of even a 1 mm thick Ti sheet would be in the order of 10 3 mU cm2 according to the resistivity of Ti metal [50], indicating the resistance of the metal is neglectable
Table 2 e A summary of the results of potentiostatic corrosion tests based on the polarization curves shown in Fig. 6.
Samples Anodic condition Icorr (mA/cm 2) Cathodic condition Icorr (mA/cm 2)
G/Ti 0.27 0.24 Ti -unpretreated 5.35 4.72 Ti-pretreated 5.18 4.25
compared with the ICR. Therefore, the TPR of a G/Ti sheet should be very approximate to two times of ICR, i.e. 8 mU cm2, which well meets the U.S. DOE 2020 target of TPR (10 mU cm2) for BP in PEMFC [35].

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
A facile method of using graphene coating to enhance the performance of Ti bipolar plates in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells has been demonstrated. Robust nanothick graphene film is coated on Ti sheet via pulse electrophoretic deposition of graphene oxide, followed by its reduction to graphene with high temperature hydrogen. Under simulated fuel cell environment, the graphene coated Ti sheet shows considerable decrease of both corrosion current and interfacial contact resistance, achieving the U.S. DOE 2020 target set for bipolar plates. Perhaps more importantly, the achievement is made via a simple process involving only easily affordable material and equipment, suggesting the
method is very promising for applications in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells.

metadata.abstractText: We report in this paper a simple method of coating very thin graphene film on titanium substrate, affording it markedly enhanced resistance to corrosion and much decreased electrical contact resistance under the environment of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC). The graphene film is formed by electrodepositing graphene oxide (GO) on Ti sheet via normal pulse voltammetry, followed by reducing the deposited GO at 500 C in hydrogen atmosphere. The resultant graphene film, with a thickness of only around 50 nm, evenly covers and covalently bonds to the Ti sheet, as revealed by SEM, Raman and XPS. Both potentiodynamic and potentiostatic tests of the graphene coated Ti (G/Ti) sample are conducted under simulated chemical environment and electrode potentials of PEMFC. Under all the circumstances, the corrosion currents of G/Ti sheet are in the order of 10 7 A/ cm, significantly less than that of bare Ti sheet. Moreover, the coated graphene film on Ti sheet leads to a much lower and more stable interfacial contact resistance (ICR) of around 4 mU cm. These results mean that the G/Ti sheet meets the U.S. DOE target of 2020 for PEMFC bipolar plates (BP) in terms of both the corrosion and electrical resistance. Therefore, the G/Ti sheet appears to be a very promising BP material in PEMFC. © 2019 Hydrogen Energy Publications LLC. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
